questions.question: What is the right order of correction of deformities in an infant with CTEV?
questions.explanation: The right order of correction of CTEV is cavus followed by adduction, then varus, and lastlyequinus (CAVE).An incorrect sequence of correction or overtreatment of CTEV can result in the development ofthe rocker-bottom foot. It is characterized by a prominent heel and a convex sole.Rocker bottom feet

questions.question: A 12-year-old with neglected CTEV and muscle wasting is brought to the hospital. A triplearthrodesis is planned. Which of the following joints will not be fused?
questions.explanation: The talocrural joint (ankle joint) is not involved in triple arthrodesis.Triple arthrodesis involves the fusion of talonavicular, talocalcaneal and calcaneocuboid joints.Triple arthrodesis is done for recurrent or persistent clubfoot deformity in older children (chroniccases). It is done after 10-12 years of age as before this age bones are not fully ossified, thereforefusion may not be adequate. questions.question: A child was brought to the orthopaedic OPD for evaluation of the given knee deformity. Whatis it known as?KX328
questions.explanation: The deformity shown is genu valgum.334A normal knee has 5-7 degrees physiological outward deviation (valgum). Any increase or decreasein angle can result in knee deformities.Knee deformities are:• Genu valgus (valgum) or knock knee - Knees are abnormally approximated and the ankles aredivergent.• Genu varus (varum) or bow knee - Knees are abnormally divergent and the ankles areapproximated.• Windswept deformity - Abnormal valgus deformity of one knee with varus of the other.• Genu recurvatum - Hyperextension at the knee joint with backwards bending.HipKneeAnkleDeformities of the kneeNormalGenu varus(Bow knees)Genu valgum(Knock knees)RROAnteriorValgusVarusWindsweptdeformityPosteriorExcessivebackwardbendingGenu recurvatum(Back knees)MARROW

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy fractured the lateral condyle of his femur. He developed malunion as acomplication. Which deformity is he most likely to develop?
questions.explanation: The boy is most likely to develop genu valgus subsequent to lateral condyle fracture of the femur.Fracture of lateral condyle femur will result in injury to the lateral growth plate of the femur, andthus only the medial condyle will continue to grow with age resulting in genu valgus.Similarly, injury to the medial growth plate of the femur will cause the lateral condyle to growonly with age, resulting in genu varus.

questions.question: Which of the following is a feature of Blount's disease?
questions.explanation: Genu varus is a feature of Blount's disease.Blount's disease, is a growth disorder of proximal tibial physis that causes the lower leg to angleinwards resulting in genu varus.Triad seen in Blount's disease:• Bilateral idiopathic genu varus• Genu recurvatum•• Internal rotation of tibia336
